entities.title: Benjamin Netanyahu
entities.description: Benjamin Netanyahu is an Israeli politician serving as the prime minister of Israel since 2009, having previously served in that role from 1996 to 1999. Netanyahu is also the chairman of the Likud – National Liberal Movement. He is the longest-serving Israeli prime minister in history and the first to be born in Israel after its Declaration of Independence.

heading: Births
txt: John Bale, English bishop and historian (d. 1563)

entities.title: John Bale
entities.description: John Bale was an English churchman, historian and controversialist, and Bishop of Ossory. He wrote the oldest known historical verse drama in English, and developed and published a very extensive list of the works of British authors down to his own time, just as the monastic libraries were being dispersed. His unhappy disposition and habit of quarrelling earned him the nickname "bilious Bale".

heading: Births
txt: Anne de Xainctonge, French saint, founded the Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin (d. 1621)

entities.title: Anne de Xainctonge
entities.description: Anne de Xainctonge was a French religious sister who founded of the Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin, the first non-cloistered women's religious community. She was declared Venerable by the Roman Catholic Church in 1991.

entities.title: Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin
entities.description: The Society of the Sisters of Saint Ursula of the Blessed Virgin is a Roman Catholic religious congregation of women founded in 1606 at Döle, France, by the Venerable Anne de Xainctonge (1587-1612). Its members are especially involved in teaching.

heading: Births
txt: Catharina Questiers, Dutch poet (d. 1669)

entities.title: Catharina Questiers
entities.description: Catharina Questiers was a Dutch poet and dramatist. Along with Cornelia van der Veer and Katharyne Lescailje she was the most successful female Dutch poet of the second half of the 17th century. Her brother David also achieved some note as a poet.

heading: Births
txt: Carlo Innocenzo Frugoni, Italian poet and academic (d. 1768)

entities.title: Carlo Innocenzo Frugoni
entities.description: Carlo Innocenzo Frugoni was an Italian poet and librettist. As a poet Frugoni was one of the best of the school of the Arcadian Academy, and his lyrics and pastorals had great facility and elegance. His collected works were published at Parma in 10 volumes in 1799, and a more complete edition appeared at Lucca in the same year in 15 volumes.

heading: Births
txt: Voltaire, French historian, playwright, and philosopher (d. 1778)

entities.title: Voltaire
entities.description: François-Marie Arouet, known by his nom de plume Voltaire, was a French Enlightenment writer, historian, and philosopher famous for his wit, his criticism of Christianity—especially the Roman Catholic Church—as well as his advocacy of freedom of speech, freedom of religion, and separation of church and state.

heading: Births
txt: Friedrich Wilhelm Marpurg, German composer, critic, and theorist (d. 1795)

entities.title: Friedrich Wilhelm Marpurg
entities.description: Friedrich Wilhelm Marpurg was a German music critic, music theorist and composer. He was friendly and active with many figures of the Enlightenment of the 18th century.

heading: Births
txt: Josiah Bartlett, American physician and politician, 6th Governor of New Hampshire (d. 1795)

entities.title: Josiah Bartlett
entities.description: Josiah Bartlett was an American physician and statesman, delegate to the Continental Congress for New Hampshire, and signatory of the Declaration of Independence. He was later Governor of New Hampshire and Chief Justice of the New Hampshire Superior Court of Judicature.

entities.title: Governor of New Hampshire
entities.description: The Governor of New Hampshire is the head of the executive branch of New Hampshire's state government.

heading: Births
txt: Joseph Plumb Martin, American sergeant (d. 1850)

entities.title: Joseph Plumb Martin
entities.description: Joseph Plumb Martin also spelled as Joseph Plum Martin in military records and recorded as Joseph P. Martin in civilian town clerk records. was a soldier in the Continental Army and Connecticut Militia during the American Revolutionary War, holding the rank of private for most of the war. His published narrative of his experiences, re-discovered in the 1950s, has become a valuable resource for his

heading: Births
txt: Friedrich Schleiermacher, German theologian, philosopher, and scholar (d. 1834)

entities.title: Friedrich Schleiermacher
entities.description: Friedrich Daniel Ernst Schleiermacher was a German Reformed theologian, philosopher, and biblical scholar known for his attempt to reconcile the criticisms of the Enlightenment with traditional Protestant Christianity. He also became influential in the evolution of higher criticism, and his work forms part of the foundation of the modern field of hermeneutics. Because of his profound effect on sub

heading: Births
txt: William Beaumont, American surgeon, "Father of Gastric Physiology" (d. 1853)

entities.title: William Beaumont
entities.description: William Beaumont was a surgeon in the U.S. Army who became known as the "Father of Gastric Physiology" following his research on human digestion.

heading: Births
txt: Samuel Cunard, Canadian businessman, founded the Cunard Line (d. 1865)

entities.title: Samuel Cunard
entities.description: Sir Samuel Cunard, 1st Baronet, was a British-Canadian shipping magnate, born in Halifax, Nova Scotia, who founded the Cunard Line. He was the son of a master carpenter and timber merchant who had fled the American Revolution and settled in Halifax.

entities.title: Cunard Line
entities.description: Cunard Line is a British cruise line based at Carnival House at Southampton, England, operated by Carnival UK and owned by Carnival Corporation & plc. Since 2011, Cunard and its three ships have been registered in Hamilton, Bermuda.

heading: Births
txt: Ludwik Gorzkowski, Polish politician, physicist, and revolutionary activist (d. 1857)

entities.title: Ludwik Gorzkowski
entities.description: Ludwik Je̜drzej Gorzkowski (1811–1857) was a Polish politician, physicist and revolutionary activist, one of the organizers of the Kraków uprising, during which he was a member of the newly formed Polish National Government alongside Jan Tyssowski and Aleksander Grzegorzewski.

heading: Births
txt: Lewis H. Morgan, American lawyer, anthropologist, and theorist (d. 1881)

entities.title: Lewis H. Morgan
entities.description: Lewis Henry Morgan  was a pioneering American anthropologist and social theorist who worked as a railroad lawyer. He is best known for his work on kinship and social structure, his theories of social evolution, and his ethnography of the Iroquois. Interested in what holds societies together, he proposed the concept that the earliest human domestic institution was the matrilineal clan, not the patr

heading: Births
txt: Hetty Green, American businesswoman and financier (d. 1916)

entities.title: Hetty Green
entities.description: Hetty Green, nicknamed the Witch of Wall Street, was an American businesswoman and financier known as "the richest woman in America" during the Gilded Age. She was named by the Guinness Book of World Records the "greatest miser". Despite her wealth, she was a renowned cheapskate, refusing to buy expensive clothes or pay for hot water, and wearing a single dress that was only replaced when it was w

heading: Births
txt: Victoria, Princess Royal of England (d. 1901)

entities.title: Victoria, Princess Royal
entities.description: Victoria, Princess Royal was German Empress and Queen of Prussia as the wife of German Emperor Frederick III. She was the eldest child of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom and Albert, Prince Consort, and was created Princess Royal in 1841. She was the mother of Wilhelm II, German Emperor.

heading: Births
txt: Désiré-Joseph Mercier, Belgian cardinal and theologian (d. 1926)

entities.title: Désiré-Joseph Mercier
entities.description: Désiré-Félicien-François-Joseph Mercier was a Belgian cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church and a noted scholar. A Thomist scholar, he had several of his works translated into other European languages. He was known for his book, Les origines de la psychologie contemporaine (1897). His scholarship gained him recognition from the Pope and he was appointed as Archbishop of Mechelen, serving from 1906

heading: Births
txt: Francisco Tárrega, Spanish guitarist and composer (d. 1909)

entities.title: Francisco Tárrega
entities.description: Francisco de Asís Tárrega y Eixea was a Spanish composer and classical guitarist of the Romantic period. He is known for such pieces as Recuerdos de la Alhambra. He is often called "the father of classical guitar" and is considered one of the greatest guitarists of all time.

heading: Births
txt: Hussein Kamel of Egypt (d. 1917)

entities.title: Hussein Kamel of Egypt
entities.description: Sultan Hussein Kamel was the Sultan of Egypt from 19 December 1914 to 9 October 1917, during the British protectorate over Egypt. He was the first person to hold the title of Sultan of Egypt since the killing of Sultan Tuman II by the Ottomans in 1517 following their conquest of Egypt.

heading: Births
txt: Pope Benedict XV (d. 1922)

entities.title: Pope Benedict XV
entities.description: Pope Benedict XV, born Giacomo Paolo Giovanni Battista della Chiesa, was head of the Catholic Church from 1914 until his death in 1922. His pontificate was largely overshadowed by World War I and its political, social, and humanitarian consequences in Europe.

heading: Births
txt: Sigbjørn Obstfelder, Norwegian poet and author (d. 1900)

entities.title: Sigbjørn Obstfelder
entities.description: Sigbjørn Obstfelder was a 19th-century Norwegian writer and poet.

heading: Births
txt: Konishiki Yasokichi I, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 17th Yokozuna (d. 1914)

entities.title: Makuuchi
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Births
txt: Alexander Berkman, Lithuanian-American activist and author (d. 1936)

entities.title: Alexander Berkman
entities.description: Alexander Berkman was a Russian-American anarchist and author. He was a leading member of the anarchist movement in the early 20th century, famous for both his political activism and his writing.

heading: Births
txt: Joe Darling, Australian cricketer and politician (d. 1946)

heading: Births
txt: Stanley Jackson, English cricketer and politician (d. 1947)

heading: Births
txt: Olav Duun, Norwegian author and educator (d. 1939)

entities.title: Olav Duun
entities.description: Olav Duun was a noteworthy author of Norwegian fiction. He is generally recognized to be one of the more outstanding writers in Norwegian literature. He once lacked only one vote to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature, and was nominated twenty-four times, in fourteen years.

heading: Births
txt: Sigfrid Karg-Elert, German composer and educator (d. 1933)

entities.title: Sigfrid Karg-Elert
entities.description: Sigfrid Karg-Elert was a German composer in the early twentieth century, best known for his compositions for organ and harmonium.

heading: Births
txt: Gustav Radbruch, German lawyer and politician, German Minister of Justice (d. 1949)

entities.title: Gustav Radbruch
entities.description: Gustav Radbruch was a German legal scholar and politician. He served as Minister of Justice of Germany during the early Weimar period. Radbruch is also regarded as one of the most influential legal philosophers of the 20th century.

entities.title: Federal Ministry of Justice (Germany)
entities.description: The Federal Ministry of Justice and Consumer Protection, abbreviated BMJV, is a cabinet-level ministry of the Federal Republic of Germany. Under the German federal system, individual States are most responsible for the administration of justice and the application of penalties. The Federal Ministry of Justice devotes itself to creating and changing law in the classic core areas related to Constitu

heading: Births
txt: Harold Nicolson, English author and politician (d. 1968)

entities.title: Harold Nicolson
entities.description: Sir Harold George Nicolson was a British politician, diplomat, historian, biographer, diarist, novelist, lecturer, journalist, broadcaster and gardener. His wife was the writer Vita Sackville-West.

heading: Births
txt: Cecil M. Harden, American politician (d. 1984)

entities.title: Cecil M. Harden
entities.description: Cecil Murray Harden was an American educator who became a Republican politician and an advocate of women's rights. She served five terms in the U.S. Representative representing Indiana's 6th congressional district. Harden was the only Republican woman elected to represent Indiana in the U.S. Congress until 2012, when Susan Brooks and Jackie Walorski were elected to serve in the 113th United States

heading: Births
txt: Mollie Steimer, Russian-American activist (d. 1980)

entities.title: Mollie Steimer
entities.description: Mollie Steimer was born as Marthe Alperine in Tsarist Russia. She emigrated to the United States with her family at the age of 15. She became an anarchist and activist who fought as a trade unionist, an anti-war activist and a free-speech campaigner.

heading: Births
txt: René Magritte, Belgian painter (d. 1967)

entities.title: René Magritte
entities.description: René François Ghislain Magritte was a Belgian surrealist artist, who became well known for creating a number of witty and thought-provoking images. Often depicting ordinary objects in an unusual context, his work is known for challenging observers' preconditioned perceptions of reality. His imagery has influenced pop art, minimalist art, and conceptual art.

heading: Births
txt: Jobyna Ralston, American actress (d. 1967)

entities.title: Jobyna Ralston
entities.description: Jobyna Ralston was an American stage and film actress. She had a featured role in the first Oscar-winning film, Wings in 1927, but is perhaps best remembered today for her on-screen chemistry with Harold Lloyd, with whom she appeared in seven movies.

heading: Births
txt: Harekrushna Mahatab, Indian journalist and politician, 1st Chief Minister of Odisha (d. 1987)

entities.title: List of Chief Ministers of Odisha
entities.description: The Chief Minister of Odisha, an Indian state, is the head of the Government of Odisha. As per the Constitution of India, the governor is the state's de jure head, but de facto executive authority rests with the chief minister. Following elections to the Odisha Legislative Assembly, the governor usually invites the party with a majority of seats to form the government. The governor appoints the ch

heading: Births
txt: Foster Hewitt, Canadian sportscaster (d. 1985)

entities.title: Foster Hewitt
entities.description: Foster William Hewitt, was a Canadian radio broadcaster most famous for his play-by-play calls for Hockey Night in Canada. He was the son of W. A. Hewitt, and the father of Bill Hewitt.

heading: Births
txt: Isaac Bashevis Singer, Polish-American novelist and short story writer, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1991)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Births
txt: Mikhail Suslov, Russian soldier, economist, and politician (d. 1982)

heading: Births
txt: Coleman Hawkins, American saxophonist and clarinet player (d. 1969)

entities.title: Coleman Hawkins
entities.description: Coleman Randolph Hawkins, nicknamed "Hawk" and sometimes "Bean", was an American jazz tenor saxophonist. One of the first prominent jazz musicians on his instrument, as Joachim E. Berendt explained: "there were some tenor players before him, but the instrument was not an acknowledged jazz horn". Hawkins biographer John Chilton described the prevalent styles of tenor saxophone solos prior to Hawkin

heading: Births
txt: Georgina Battiscombe, British biographer (d. 2006)

entities.title: Georgina Battiscombe
entities.description: Georgina Battiscombe was a British biographer, specialising mainly in lives from the Victorian era.

heading: Births
txt: Buck Ram, American songwriter and music producer (d. 1991)

entities.title: Buck Ram
entities.description: Samuel "Buck" Ram was an American songwriter, and popular music producer and arranger. He was one of BMI's top five songwriters/air play in its first 50 years, alongside Paul Simon, Kris Kristofferson, Jimmy Webb, and Paul McCartney. He is best known for his long association with The Platters and also wrote, produced and arranged for the Penguins, the Coasters, the Drifters, Ike and Tina Turner, I

heading: Births
txt: Leo Politi, Italian-American author and illustrator (d. 1996)

entities.title: Leo Politi
entities.description: Atiglio Leoni Politi was an American artist and author who wrote and illustrated some 20 children's books, as well as Bunker Hill, Los Angeles (1964), intended for adults. His works often celebrated cultural diversity, and many were published in both English and Spanish.

heading: Births
txt: Elizabeth George Speare, American author and educator (d. 1994)

heading: Births
txt: Eleanor Powell, American actress and dancer (d. 1982)

entities.title: Eleanor Powell
entities.description: Eleanor Torrey Powell was an American dancer and actress. Best remembered for her tap dance numbers in musical films in the 1930s and 1940s, Powell began studying ballet when she was six and was dancing at nightclubs in Atlantic City before she was a teenager. At the age of sixteen, she began studying tap and started appearing in musical revues on Broadway. She made her Hollywood debut as a featur

heading: Births
txt: John Boulting, English director, producer, and screenwriter (d. 1985)

entities.title: John Boulting
entities.description: John Edward Boulting and Roy Alfred Clarence Boulting, known collectively as the Boulting brothers, were English filmmakers and identical twins who became known for their popular series of satirical comedies in the 1950s and 1960s. They produced many of their films through their own production company, Charter Film Productions, which they set up in 1937.

heading: Births
txt: Roy Boulting, English director, producer, and screenwriter (d. 2001)

heading: Births
txt: Gunnar Kangro, Estonian mathematician, author, and academic (d. 1975)

heading: Births
txt: Nusret Fişek, Turkish physician and politician, Turkish Minister of Health (d. 1990)

entities.title: Nusret Fişek
entities.description: Nusret Hasan Fişek was a Turkish physician and Minister of Health.

entities.title: Ministry of Health (Turkey)
entities.description: The Ministry of Health is the ministry of the Government of Turkey responsible for proposing and executing the government policy on health, planning and providing healthcare and protecting consumers. Likewise, it is responsible for proposing and executing the government policy on social cohesion and inclusion, family, protection of minors, youth and of care for dependent or disabled persons. The M

heading: Births
txt: Henri Laborit, French physician and philosopher (d. 1995)

heading: Births
txt: Norm Smith, Australian footballer and coach (d. 1973)

entities.title: Norm Smith
entities.description: Norman Walter "Norm" Smith was an Australian rules football player and coach in the Victorian Football League (VFL). After 200 games as a player with Melbourne and Fitzroy, Smith began a twenty-year coaching career, including a fifteen-year stint at Melbourne. Recognised as the father of modern Australian football coaching, Smith coached Melbourne to six premierships and in 1996 was chosen as the

heading: Births
txt: Sid Luckman, American football player and soldier (d. 1998)

entities.title: Sid Luckman
entities.description: Sidney Luckman was an American football quarterback for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League (NFL) from 1939 through 1950. During his 12 seasons with the Bears he led them to four NFL championships.

heading: Births
txt: Chung Il-kwon, Korean politician, diplomat, and soldier (d.1994)

entities.title: Chung Il-kwon
entities.description: Chung Il-kwon, and was also known by the Japanese pronunciation of his name - Ikken Tei was a South Korean politician, diplomat, and soldier. entities.description: Lennard "Len" Väljas is a Canadian former cross-country skier. He was born in Toronto, and is of Estonian descent. He is the younger brother of Canadian beach volleyball Olympian Kristina May.

heading: Births
txt: Almaz Ayana, Ethiopian sprinter

entities.title: Almaz Ayana
entities.description: Almaz Ayana Eba is an Ethiopian female long-distance runner who competes in the 3000 metres, 5000 metres, and 10,000 metres events. She broke the 10,000 metres world record, set in 1993, while winning the gold medal at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. At the 2017 World Championships in London, Almaz won the gold medal in the 10,000 metres, finishing 46 seconds ahead of the runner-up.

entities.description: Saúl Ñíguez Esclápez, known as Saúl, is a Spanish professional footballer who plays as a central or defensive midfielder for Atlético Madrid and the Spain national team.

heading: Births
txt: Jaelin Howell, American soccer player

entities.title: Jaelin Howell
entities.description: Jaelin Marie Howell is an American soccer player. She has represented the United States on the under-17 national team. In March 2017, she was called up to the senior national team for two international friendlies against Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Columbanus, Irish missionary and saint (b. 543)

entities.title: Columbanus
entities.description: Columbanus was an Irish missionary notable for founding a number of monasteries after 590 in the Frankish and Lombard kingdoms, most notably Luxeuil Abbey in present-day France and Bobbio Abbey in present-day Italy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Al-Tahawi, Arab imam and scholar (b. 853)

entities.title: Al-Tahawi
entities.description: Abu Ja'far Ahmad al-Tahawi, or simply aṭ-Ṭaḥāwī, was an Egyptian Arab Hanafi jurist and a hadith scholar. He studied with al-Muzani and was a Shafi'i jurist, then with Ahmad b. Imran and followed the Hanafi school. He is known for his work al-'Aqidah al-Tahawiyyah, a summary of Sunni Islamic creed which influenced Hanafis in Egypt.

heading: Deaths
txt: Reizei, emperor of Japan (b. 950)

entities.title: Emperor Reizei
entities.description: Emperor Reizei  was the 63rd emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession.

heading: Deaths
txt: William de Corbeil, English archbishop (b. 1070)

entities.title: William de Corbeil
entities.description: William de Corbeil or William of Corbeil was a medieval Archbishop of Canterbury. Very little is known of William's early life or his family, except that he was born at Corbeil, south of Paris, and that he had two brothers. Educated as a theologian, he taught briefly before serving the bishops of Durham and London as a clerk and subsequently becoming an Augustinian canon. William was elected to th

heading: Deaths
txt: García Ramírez of Navarre (b. 1112)

entities.title: García Ramírez of Navarre
entities.description: García Ramírez, sometimes García IV, V, VI or VII, called the Restorer, was the King of Navarre (Pamplona) from 1134. The election of García Ramírez restored the independence of the Navarrese kingdom after 58 years of political union with the Kingdom of Aragon. After some initial conflict he would align himself with king Alfonso VII of León and Castile, and as his ally take part in the Reconquista

heading: Deaths
txt: Yury of Moscow, Prince of Moscow and Vladimir

entities.title: Yury of Moscow
entities.description: Yuriy Danilovich, also known as Georgiy Danilovich was Prince of Moscow (1303–1325) and Grand Prince of Vladimir.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip I, Duke of Burgundy (b. 1346)

entities.title: Philip I, Duke of Burgundy
entities.description: Philip of Rouvres was the Count of Burgundy and Count of Artois from 1347, Duke of Burgundy from 1349, and Count of Auvergne and Boulogne from 1360. He was the only son of Philip, heir to the Duchy of Burgundy, and Joan I, heiress of Auvergne and Boulogne.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georgius Agricola, German mineralogist, philologist, and scholar (b. 1490)

entities.title: Georgius Agricola
entities.description: Georgius Agricola was a German Humanist scholar, mineralogist and metallurgist. Born in the small town of Glauchau, in the Electorate of Saxony of the Holy Roman Empire, he was broadly educated, but took a particular interest in the mining and refining of metals.

heading: Deaths
txt: Annibale Caro, Italian poet and author (b. 1507)

entities.title: Annibale Caro
entities.description: Fra' Annibale Caro, K.M., was an Italian writer and poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Gresham, English merchant and financier (b. 1519)

entities.title: Thomas Gresham
entities.description: Sir Thomas Gresham the Elder, was an English merchant and financier who acted on behalf of King Edward VI (1547–1553) and Edward's half-sisters, queens Mary I (1553–1558) and Elizabeth I (1558–1603).

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Grey, 8th Earl of Kent, English politician, Lord Lieutenant of Bedfordshire (b. 1583)

entities.title: Henry Grey, 8th Earl of Kent
entities.description: Henry Grey, 8th Earl of Kent of Wrest Park, Bedfordshire was Earl of Kent from 1623 to his death.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Bedfordshire
entities.description: This is a list of people who have served as Lord Lieutenant of Bedfordshire. Since 1711, all Lords Lieutenant have also been Custos Rotulorum of Bedfordshire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jan Brożek, Polish mathematician, physician, and astronomer (b. 1585)

entities.title: Jan Brożek
entities.description: Jan Brożek was a Polish polymath: a mathematician, astronomer, physician, poet, writer, musician and rector of the Kraków Academy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Purcell, English organist and composer (b. 1659)

entities.title: Henry Purcell
entities.description: Henry Purcell was an English composer. Although he incorporated Italian and French stylistic elements, Purcell's was a uniquely English form of Baroque music. He is generally considered to be one of the greatest English composers; no later native-born English composer approached his fame until Edward Elgar, Ralph Vaughan Williams, Gustav Holst, William Walton and Benjamin Britten in the 20th centu

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernardo Pasquini, Italian organist and composer (b. 1637)

entities.title: Bernardo Pasquini
entities.description: Bernardo Pasquini was an Italian composer of operas, oratorios, cantatas and keyboard music. A renowned virtuoso keyboard player in his day, he was one of the most important Italian composers for harpsichord between Girolamo Frescobaldi and Domenico Scarlatti, having also made substantial contributions to the opera and oratorio.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Hill, English botanist and author (b. 1719)

entities.title: John Hill (botanist)
entities.description: "Sir" John Hill was an English composer, actor, author and botanist. He contributed to contemporary periodicals and engaged in literary battles with poets, playwrights and scientists. He is remembered for his illustrated botanical compendium The Vegetable System, one of the first works to use the nomenclature of Carl Linnaeus. In recognition of his efforts, he was created a knight of the Order of

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques de Vaucanson, French engineer (b. 1709)

entities.title: Jacques de Vaucanson
entities.description: Jacques de Vaucanson was a French inventor and artist who was responsible for the creation of impressive and innovative automata. He also was the first person to design an automatic loom and built the first all-metal lathe.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich von Kleist, German poet and author (b. 1777)

entities.title: Heinrich von Kleist
entities.description: Bernd Heinrich Wilhelm von Kleist was a German poet, dramatist, novelist, short story writer and journalist. His best known works are the theatre plays Das Käthchen von Heilbronn, The Broken Jug, Amphitryon, Penthesilea and the novellas Michael Kohlhaas and The Marquise of O. Kleist committed suicide together with a close female friend who was terminally ill.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ivan Krylov, Russian poet and playwright (b. 1769)

entities.title: Ivan Krylov
entities.description: Ivan Andreyevich Krylov is Russia's best-known fabulist and probably the most epigrammatic of all Russian authors. Formerly a dramatist and journalist, he only discovered his true genre at the age of 40. While many of his earlier fables were loosely based on Aesop's and La Fontaine's, later fables were original work, often with a satirical bent.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yoshida Shōin, Japanese academic and politician (b. 1830)

entities.title: Yoshida Shōin
entities.description: Yoshida Shōin , commonly named Torajirō (寅次郎), was one of Japan's most distinguished intellectuals in the late years of the Tokugawa shogunate. He devoted himself to nurturing many ishin shishi who in turn made major contributions to the Meiji Restoration.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Baptiste Henri Lacordaire, French priest and activist (b. 1802)

entities.title: Jean-Baptiste Henri Lacordaire
entities.description: Jean-Baptiste Henri-Dominique Lacordaire, often styled Henri-Dominique Lacordaire, was a French ecclesiastic, preacher, journalist, theologian and political activist. He re-established the Dominican Order in post-Revolutionary France. Lacordaire was reputed to be the greatest pulpit orator of the nineteenth century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karel Jaromír Erben, Czech historian and poet (b. 1811)

entities.title: Karel Jaromír Erben
entities.description: Karel Jaromír Erben was a Czech folklorist and poet of the mid-19th century, best known for his collection Kytice , which contains poems based on traditional and folkloric themes.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marià Fortuny, Spanish painter (b. 1838)

entities.title: Marià Fortuny
entities.description: Marià Josep Maria Bernat Fortuny i Marsal, known more simply as Marià Fortuny or Mariano Fortuny, was the leading Spanish painter of his day, with an international reputation. His brief career encompassed works on a variety of subjects common in the art of the period, including the Romantic fascination with Orientalist themes, historicist genre painting, military painting of Spanish colonial expan

heading: Deaths
txt: Ami Boué, German-Austrian geologist and ethnographer (b. 1794)

entities.title: Ami Boué
entities.description: Ami Boué was a geologist of French Huguenot origin. Born at Hamburg he trained in Edinburgh and across Europe. He travelled across Europe, studying geology, as well as ethnology, and is considered to be among the first to produce a geological map of the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Garret Hobart, American lawyer and politician, 24th Vice President of the United States (b. 1844)

entities.title: Garret Hobart
entities.description: Garret Augustus Hobart was the 24th vice president of the United States, serving from 1897 until his death in 1899. He was the sixth American vice president to die in office. Prior to serving as vice president, Hobart was an influential New Jersey politician and political operative.

entities.title: Vice President of the United States
entities.description: The vice president of the United States (VPOTUS) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, and ranks first in the presidential line of succession. The vice president is also an officer in the legislative branch, as the president of the Senate. In this capacity, the vice president is empowered to preside over Sena

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Boyle, Australian cricketer (b. 1847)

entities.title: Harry Boyle (cricketer)
entities.description: Henry Frederick "Harry" Boyle was a leading Australian Test cricketer of the late 1870s and early 1880s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paula Modersohn-Becker, German painter (b. 1876)

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Friedrich Schmidt, German-Russian geologist and botanist (b. 1832)

entities.title: Carl Friedrich Schmidt (1832)
entities.description: Carl Friedrich Schmidt was a Baltic German geologist and botanist in the Russian Empire. He is acknowledged as the founder of Estonian geology. In the mid-19th century, he researched Estonian oil shale, kukersite, and named it as kuckers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peder Severin Krøyer, Norwegian-Danish painter (b. 1851)

entities.title: Peder Severin Krøyer
entities.description: Peder Severin Krøyer, professionally known as P. S. Krøyer, was a Danish painter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Joseph I of Austria (b. 1830)

entities.title: Franz Joseph I of Austria
entities.description: Franz Joseph I or Francis Joseph I was Emperor of Austria, King of Hungary, Croatia, and Bohemia, and monarch of other states of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, from 2 December 1848 until his death. From 1 May 1850 to 24 August 1866 he was also President of the German Confederation. He was the longest-reigning ruler of Austria and Hungary, as well as the sixth-longest-reigning monarch of any country

heading: Deaths
txt: Ricardo Flores Magón, Mexican journalist and activist (b. 1874)

entities.title: Ricardo Flores Magón
entities.description: Cipriano Ricardo Flores Magón was a noted Mexican anarchist and social reform activist. His brothers Enrique and Jesús were also active in politics. Followers of the Flores Magón brothers were known as Magonistas. He has been considered an important participant in the social movement that sparked the Mexican Revolution.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Cummins, American golfer (b. 1886)

entities.title: Edward Cummins
entities.description: Edward McClellan "Ned" Cummins was an American golfer who competed in the 1904 Summer Olympics. In 1904 he was part of the American team which won the gold medal. He finished 25th in this competition. In the individual competition he finished 25th in the qualification and was eliminated in the first round of the match play.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line (b. 1858)

entities.title: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line
entities.description: Heinrich XXVII, Prince Reuss Younger Line was the last reigning Prince Reuss Younger Line from 1913 to 1918. Then he became Head of the House of Reuss Younger Line from 1918 to 1928.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Scaddan, Australian politician, 10th Premier of Western Australia (b. 1876)

entities.title: John Scaddan
entities.description: John Scaddan, CMG, popularly known as "Happy Jack", was Premier of Western Australia from 7 October 1911 until 27 July 1916.

entities.title: Premier of Western Australia
entities.description: The Premier of Western Australia is the head of the executive branch of government in the Australian state of Western Australia. The Premier has similar functions in Western Australia to those performed by the Prime Minister of Australia at the national level, subject to the different Constitutions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leopold Godowsky, Polish-American pianist and composer (b. 1870)

entities.title: Leopold Godowsky
entities.description: Leopold Godowsky was a Polish-American virtuoso pianist, composer and teacher. He was one of the most highly regarded performers of his time, known for his theories concerning the application of relaxed weight and economy of motion within pianistic technique – principles later propagated by Godowsky's pupils, such as Heinrich Neuhaus.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henrietta Vinton Davis, American actress and playwright (b. 1860)

entities.title: Henrietta Vinton Davis
entities.description: Henrietta Vinton Davis was an African-American elocutionist, dramatist, and impersonator. In addition to being "the premier actor of all nineteenth-century black performers on the dramatic stage", Davis was proclaimed by Marcus Garvey to be the "greatest woman of the Negro race today".

heading: Deaths
txt: Count Leopold Berchtold, Austrian-Hungarian politician, Foreign Minister of Austria-Hungary (b. 1863)

entities.title: Count Leopold Berchtold
entities.description: Leopold Anton Johann Sigismund Josef Korsinus Ferdinand Graf Berchtold von und zu Ungarschitz, Frättling und Püllütz, was an Austro-Hungarian politician, diplomat and statesman who served as Imperial Foreign Minister at the outbreak of World War I.

entities.title: List of foreign ministers of Austria-Hungary
entities.description: This is a list of foreign ministers of the Habsburg Monarchy, of the Austrian Empire, and of Austria-Hungary up to 1918.

heading: Deaths
txt: J. B. M. Hertzog, South African general and politician, 3rd Prime Minister of South Africa (b. 1866)

entities.title: Prime Minister of South Africa
entities.description: The prime minister of South Africa was the head of government in South Africa between 1910 and 1984.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Benchley,  American humorist, newspaper columnist, and actor (b. 1889)

entities.title: Robert Benchley
entities.description: Robert Charles Benchley was an American humorist best known for his work as a newspaper columnist and film actor. From his beginnings at The Harvard Lampoon while attending Harvard University, through his many years writing essays and articles for Vanity Fair and The New Yorker and his acclaimed short films, Benchley's style of humor brought him respect and success during his life, from his peers

entities.description: The Premier of Queensland is the head of government in the Australian state of Queensland.

entities.title: Felice Bonetto
entities.description: Felice Bonetto was a courageous racing driver who earned the nickname Il Pirata.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Burton Harrison, American general and politician, 6th Governor-General of the Philippines (b. 1873)

entities.title: Francis Burton Harrison
entities.description: Francis Burton Harrison was an American-born Filipino statesman who served in the United States House of Representatives and was appointed Governor-General of the Philippines by President of the United States Woodrow Wilson. Harrison was a prominent adviser to the president of the Philippine Commonwealth, as well as the next four Presidents of the Republic of the Philippines. He is the only former

entities.title: Governor-General of the Philippines
entities.description: The Governor-General of the Philippines was the title of the government executive during the colonial period of the Philippines, governed mainly by Spain (1565–1898) and the United States (1898–1946), and briefly by Great Britain (1762–1764) and Japan (1942–1945). They were also the representative of the executive of the ruling power.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mel Ott, American baseball player, manager, and sportscaster (b. 1909)

entities.title: Mel Ott
entities.description: Melvin Thomas Ott, nicknamed "Master Melvin", was an American professional baseball right fielder, who played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the New York Giants, from 1926 through 1947.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Baer, American boxer, referee, and actor (b. 1909)

entities.title: Max Baer (boxer)
entities.description: Maximilian Adelbert Baer was an American professional boxer who was the world heavyweight champion from June 14, 1934, to June 13, 1935. His fights were both rated Fight of the Year by The Ring magazine. Baer was also a boxing referee, and had an occasional role on film or television. He was the brother of heavyweight boxing contender Buddy Baer and father of actor Max Baer Jr.. Baer is rated #22

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Amyot, Canadian canoeist (b. 1904)

entities.title: Frank Amyot
entities.description: Francis "Frank" Amyot was a Canadian sprint canoeist who competed in the 1930s. He won Canada's only gold medal at the 1936 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Artur Lemba, Estonian composer and educator (b. 1885)

entities.title: Artur Lemba
entities.description: Artur Lemba was an Estonian composer and piano teacher, and one of the most important figures in Estonian classical music. Artur and his older brother Theodor (1876-1962) were the first professional pianists in Estonia to give concerts abroad. Artur's 1905 opera Sabina was the first opera composed by an Estonian. His Symphony No. 1 in 1908 was the first symphony composed by an Estonian.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Stroud, American ornithologist and author (b. 1890)

heading: Deaths
txt: Catherine Bauer Wurster, American architect and public housing advocate (b. 1905)

entities.title: Catherine Bauer Wurster
entities.description: Catherine Krouse Bauer Wurster  was an American public housing advocate and educator of city planners and urban planners. A leading member of the "housers," a group of planners who advocated affordable housing for low-income families, she dramatically changed social housing practice and law in the United States. Wurster's influential book Modern Housing was published by Houghton Mifflin Company in

heading: Deaths
txt: C. M. Eddy, Jr., American author (b. 1896)

entities.title: C. M. Eddy, Jr.
entities.description: Clifford Martin Eddy Jr. was an American author known for his horror, mystery and supernatural short stories. He is best remembered for his work in Weird Tales magazine and his friendship with H. P. Lovecraft.

heading: Deaths
txt: Newsy Lalonde, Canadian lacrosse and ice hockey player (b. 1887)

entities.title: Newsy Lalonde
entities.description: Édouard Cyrille "Newsy" Lalonde was a Canadian professional ice hockey forward in the National Hockey League (NHL) and a professional lacrosse player. Lalonde is regarded as one of hockey's and lacrosse's greatest players of the first half of the 20th century and one of Canadian sport's most colourful characters. He played for the Montreal Canadiens – considered to be the original "Flying Frenchma

heading: Deaths
txt: C. V. Raman, Indian physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1888)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Pelly, American lawyer and politician (b. 1902)

entities.title: Thomas Pelly
entities.description: Thomas Minor Pelly was a U.S. Representative from Washington.

heading: Deaths
txt: John B. Gambling, American radio host (b. 1897)

entities.title: John B. Gambling
entities.description: John Bradley Gambling was an American radio personality. He was a member of the Gambling family, 3 generations of whom—John B., John A. and John R.—were hosts of WOR Radio's morning show Rambling with Gambling over the course of over 75 years.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Martin, Swiss-Dutch pianist and composer (b. 1890)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gunnar Gunnarsson, Icelandic author (b. 1889)

entities.title: Gunnar Gunnarsson
entities.description: Gunnar Gunnarsson was an Icelandic author who wrote mainly in Danish. He grew up, in considerable poverty, on Valþjófsstaður in Fljótsdalur valley and on Ljótsstaðir in Vopnafjörður. During the first half of 20th century he became one of the most popular novelists in Denmark and Germany. One time he went to Germany and had a meeting with Hitler and is considered to be the only Icelander who has me

heading: Deaths
txt: Sara García, Mexican actress (b. 1895)

entities.title: Sara García
entities.description: Sara García Hidalgo was a Mexican actress who made her biggest mark during the "Golden Age of Mexican cinema". During the 1940s and 1950s, she often played the part of a no-nonsense but lovable grandmother in numerous Mexican films. In later years, she played parts in Mexican telenovelas.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry von Zell, American actor and comedian (b. 1906)

entities.title: Harry von Zell
entities.description: Harry Rudolph von Zell was an American announcer of radio programs, and an actor in films and television shows. He is best remembered for his work on The George Burns and Gracie Allen Show, and for once mispronouncing President Herbert Hoover's name on the air, a slip that was exaggerated on a later comedy record album.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Hargrave, English activist and author (b. 1894)

entities.title: John Hargrave
entities.description: John Gordon Hargrave, , was a prominent youth leader in Britain during the 1920s and 1930s, Head Man of the Kibbo Kift, described in his obituary as an 'author, cartoonist, inventor, lexicographer, artist and psychic healer'. He was a Utopian thinker, a believer in both science and magic, and a figure-head for the Social Credit movement in British politics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ben Wilson, American basketball player (b. 1967)

entities.title: Ben Wilson (basketball)
entities.description: Benjamin Wilson Jr. was an American high school basketball player from Chicago, Illinois. Wilson, a Neal F. Simeon Vocational High School basketball player was regarded as the top high school player in the U.S. by scouts and coaches attending the 1984 Athletes For Better Education basketball camp. Wilson is noted as the first Chicago athlete to receive this honor. On November 21, 1984, Wilson died

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerry Colonna, American singer-songwriter and actor (b. 1904)

entities.title: Jerry Colonna (entertainer)
entities.description: Gerardo Luigi Colonna, better known as Jerry Colonna, was an American musician, actor, comedian, singer, songwriter and trombonist who played the zaniest of Bob Hope's sidekicks in Hope's popular radio shows and films of the 1940s and 1950s. He also voiced the March Hare in Disney's 1951 animated film Alice in Wonderland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Hubbell, American baseball player and scout (b. 1903)

entities.title: Carl Hubbell
entities.description: Carl Owen Hubbell, nicknamed "The Meal Ticket" and "King Carl", was an American Major League Baseball player. He was a pitcher for the New York Giants of the National League from 1928 to 1943, and remained on the team's payroll for the rest of his life, long after their move to San Francisco.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harvey Hart, Canadian director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1928)

entities.title: Harvey Hart
entities.description: Harvey Hart was a Canadian television and film director and a television producer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Margot Zemach, American author and illustrator (b. 1931)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dean Hart, Canadian wrestler and referee (b. 1954)

entities.title: Dean Hart
entities.description: Dean Harry Anthony Hart was a Canadian–American amateur wrestler, professional wrestler, referee, wrestling as well as music promoter and member of the Hart family who wrestled in Canadian regional promotions during the 1970s and 1980s, most notably in the Calgary-based Stampede Wrestling. He was the son of Stu and Helen Hart and the younger brother of Smith, Bruce, Keith and Wayne, as well as old

heading: Deaths
txt: Sonny Werblin, American businessman and philanthropist (b. 1907)

entities.title: Sonny Werblin
entities.description: David Abraham "Sonny" Werblin was a prominent entertainment industry executive and sports impresario who was an owner of the New York Jets and chairman of Madison Square Garden, and who built and managed the Meadowlands Sports Complex.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kaysone Phomvihane, Laotian soldier and politician, 2nd President of Laos (b. 1920)

entities.title: Kaysone Phomvihane
entities.description: Kaysone Phomvihane was the first leader of the Communist Lao People's Revolutionary Party from 1955 until his death in 1992. After the Communists seized power in the wake of the Laotian Civil War, he was the de facto leader of Laos from 1975 until his death. He served as the first Prime Minister of the Lao People's Democratic Republic from 1975 to 1991 and then as the second President from 1991 to

entities.title: President of Laos
entities.description: The President of the Lao People's Democratic Republic is the head of state of Laos. The current president is Thongloun Sisoulith, since 22 March 2021. He was previously elected as the General Secretary of the Lao People's Revolutionary Party, Laos' most powerful position in January 2021, ranking him first in the Politburo.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ricky Williams, American singer-songwriter and drummer (b. 1956)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Bixby, American actor (b. 1934)

entities.title: Bill Bixby
entities.description: Wilfred Bailey Everett "Bill" Bixby III was an American actor, director, producer, and frequent game-show panelist. His career spanned more than three decades, including appearances on stage, in films, and on television series. He is known for his roles as Tim O'Hara in the CBS sitcom My Favorite Martian, Tom Corbett in the ABC sitcom The Courtship of Eddie's Father, stage illusionist Anthony Blak

heading: Deaths
txt: Willem Jacob Luyten, Dutch-American astronomer and academic (b. 1899)

entities.description: Willem Jacob Luyten was a Dutch-American astronomer.

txt: Peter Grant, English actor and manager (b. 1935)

entities.title: Peter Grant (music manager)
entities.description: Peter Grant was an English music manager, who is widely known as the manager of Led Zeppelin from their creation in 1968 to their breakup in 1980. With his intimidating size and weight, confrontational manner, and knowledge and experience, he procured strong, and unprecedented, deals for his band, and is widely credited with improving pay and conditions for all musicians in dealings with concert p

entities.title: List of Ambassadors of the United Kingdom to Kazakhstan
entities.description: The Ambassador of the United Kingdom to Kazakhstan is the United Kingdom's foremost diplomatic representative in the Republic of Kazakhstan, and head of the UK's diplomatic mission in Nur-Sultan. The official title is Her Britannic Majesty's Ambassador to the Republic of Kazakhstan.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard Rose, English organist and composer (b 1916)

entities.title: Bernard Rose (musician)
entities.description: Bernard William George Rose, OBE, Doctor in Music, Fellow of the Royal College of Organists, was a British organist, soldier, composer, and academic.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Quentin Crisp, English actor, author, and illustrator (b. 1908)

entities.title: Quentin Crisp
entities.description: Quentin Crisp was an English writer, raconteur and actor. From a conventional suburban background, Crisp wore make-up and painted his nails. During his teen years he worked briefly as a rent boy. He then spent thirty years as a professional model for life-classes in art colleges. The interviews he gave about his unusual life attracted great curiosity and he was soon sought after for his personal v

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernest Lluch, Spanish economist and politician (b. 1937)

entities.title: Ernest Lluch
entities.description: Ernest Lluch Martín, was a Spanish economist and politician, member of the Socialists' Party of Catalonia (PSC). He was Minister of Health and Consumption from 1982 to 1986 in the first Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) government of Felipe González. He was assassinated in 2000 by the Basque separatist organisation, ETA.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hadda Brooks, American singer-songwriter and pianist (b. 1916)

entities.title: Hadda Brooks
entities.description: Hadda Brooks was an American pianist, vocalist and composer. Her first single, "Swingin' the Boogie", which she composed, was issued in 1945. She was billed as "Queen of the Boogie". She sang at Hawaii's statehood ceremony in 1959 and was asked for a private audience by Pope Pius XII.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Anderson, Scottish soldier (b. 1896)

entities.title: Alfred Anderson (veteran)
entities.description: Alfred Anderson was a Scottish joiner and veteran of the First World War. He was the last known holder of the 1914 Star, the last known combatant to participate in the 1914 World War I Christmas truce, Scotland's last known World War I veteran, and Scotland's oldest man for more than a year.

entities.title: Hassan Gouled Aptidon
entities.description: Hassan Gouled Aptidon was the first President of Djibouti from 1977 to 1999.

entities.title: President of Djibouti
entities.description: This is a list of presidents of Djibouti. Since the establishment of the office of president in 1977, there have been two presidents. The president is both head of state and head of government of Djibouti and the commander-in-chief of the Djibouti Armed Forces. The current president is Ismaïl Omar Guelleh, since 1999.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths
txt: Fernando Fernán Gómez, Spanish actor, director, and screenwriter (b. 1921)

entities.title: Fernando Fernán Gómez
entities.description: Fernando Fernández Gómez better known as Fernando Fernán-Gómez was a Spanish-Peruvian actor, screenwriter, film director, theater director and member of the Royal Spanish Academy for seven years. He was born in Peru while his mother, Spanish actress Carola Fernán-Gómez, was making a tour in Latin America. He would later use her surname for his stage name when he moved to Spain in 1924.

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantin Feoktistov, Russian engineer and astronaut (b. 1926)

entities.title: Konstantin Feoktistov
entities.description: Konstantin Petrovich Feoktistov was a Soviet cosmonaut and an eminent space engineer. As a cosmonaut Feoktistov flew on Voskhod 1, the first spacecraft to carry three crew members. Feoktistov also wrote several books on space technology and exploration. The Feoktistov crater on the far side of the Moon is named in his honor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Norris Church Mailer, American author (b. 1949)

entities.title: Norris Church Mailer
entities.description: Norris Church Mailer was an American novelist, actress, artist, and model. Norris published two novels, Windchill Summer and Cheap Diamonds, and a memoir, A Ticket to the Circus, which focuses on her nearly thirty-year marriage to Norman Mailer.

entities.title: DuSable Museum of African American History
entities.description: The DuSable Museum of African American History in Chicago is dedicated to the study and conservation of African-American history, culture, and art. It was founded in 1961 by Margaret Taylor-Burroughs, her husband Charles Burroughs, Gerard Lew, Eugene Feldman, Bernard Goss, Marian M. Hadley, and others. They established the museum to celebrate black culture, at the time overlooked by most museums a

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne McCaffrey, American science fiction and fantasy author (b. 1926)

entities.title: Anne McCaffrey
entities.description: Anne Inez McCaffrey was an American-Irish writer known for the Dragonriders of Pern science fiction series. She was the first woman to win a Hugo Award for fiction and the first to win a Nebula Award. Her 1978 novel The White Dragon became one of the first science-fiction books to appear on the New York Times Best Seller list.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emily Squires, American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1941)

entities.title: Emily Squires
entities.description: Emily Squires was an American television producer and director best known for her Emmy Award-winning work on Sesame Street.

entities.title: John Egerton (journalist)
entities.description: John Egerton was an American journalist and author known for his writing on the Civil Rights Movement, Southern food, history of the South, and Southern culture.

entities.title: Kavli Foundation (United States)
entities.description: The Kavli Foundation, based in Los Angeles, California, is a foundation that supports the advancement of science and the increase of public understanding and support for scientists and their work.

entities.title: John H. Land
entities.description: John Horting Land was Mayor of Apopka, Florida for a total of 61 years, from 1950 to 1968 and again from 1971 to 2014. He was the longest-serving mayor in the history of Florida and one of the longest-serving mayors in the United States. After having served continuously since 1971, Land was defeated in a bid for re-election by Joe Kilsheimer on April 8, 2014.

entities.title: Hassan Sadpara
entities.description: Hassan Sadpara PP was a Pakistani mountaineer and adventurer from Skardu in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. He is the first Pakistani to have climbed six eight-thousanders including the world's highest peak Everest (8848m), K2 (8611m), Gasherbrum I (8080m), Gasherbrum II (8034m), Nanga Parbat and Broad Peak (8051m). He is also credited for summiting five of the eight-thousanders without using suppleme

heading: Deaths
txt: David Cassidy, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1950)

entities.title: David Cassidy
entities.description: David Bruce Cassidy was an American actor, singer, songwriter, and guitarist. He was best known for his role as Keith Partridge, the son of Shirley Partridge, in the 1970s musical-sitcom The Partridge Family. This role catapulted Cassidy to teen idol status as a superstar pop singer of the 1970s.
